action were about global cooperation

on divvying up the costs of
mitigation of decarbonization.

When we think about making progress
towards a clean energy economy,

we often think about the
cost of clean technologies.

It's higher than the
technologies we have right now.

And cost is a big problem,
but it's not the only one.

We need to think about which of
these coordination problems can

private sector actors
solve themselves,

and where does the
government need to come in?

Central banks are not the
only actors trying to manage
these new climate transition risks.

Financial supervisors are
also exploring this space.

Investing in new energy
technologies is costly.

And if government tries to force
companies and households to do that,

there might be a lot of
political resistance.

I'm Jonas Meckling. I'm a professor at
the University of California, Berkeley,

and a climate fellow at
Harvard Business School BiGS.

While it's still premature to predict the
outcomes under the new administration,
what is your perspective on the IRA?

I think really two big
perspectives on this.

There's one view that says
that the IRA will likely
be cut and gutted to a large extent,

because the Trump administration
is also pursuing a tax cut agenda.

So they'll be looking for
savings wherever they can.

Another view is, well,
the IRA is sticky

because there are a bunch of Republican
constituencies that benefit from it.

There are Republican states
that have invested substantially
in clean energy manufacturing.

But also industries that are core
constituency of the Republican Party,

like oil and gas, has invested
in some low carbon technologies.

And in fact, even before the election,
 the oil and gas industry

lobbied the Trump campaign to
keep some key IRA provisions

that support oil and gas
investments in hydrogen,

in renewable fuels,
but also carbon capture and storage.

So those are two very different views, and
I think in a few months we'll know more.

How should business leaders
be thinking about this,

since we have some
uncertainty right now?

I mean,
the uncertainty is huge and real.

There's a lot of
policy uncertainty,

and has impacted action
investments over the last year.

We saw a lower uptake of IRA provision
or incentives over the last year,

as business investors were navigating
the uncertainty around the election.

But now it's really about making
the case to the Trump administration

that the IRA incentives are
actually good for the U.S. economy,

and have a place in what the
Trump or incoming administration

is calling the energy
dominance agenda for the U.S.
And that can be done individually,

that companies lobby individually
make their case, they're doing so,

but also through trade associations,
collectively conveying that.

President Trump signed an executive order,
and it relates to electric vehicles.

What is your perspective on
what may happen with that?

There is a lot of headwind
coming on three fronts.

One is that the tax credit
in the IRA for electric vehicles
may be cut back to some extent.

Another one is that the EPA tailpipe
emission rule, that that might be repealed.

And lastly, that corporate average
fuel economy standards, CAFE standards,
might be relaxed.

All of that would reduce
demand for electric vehicles.

And what strategies might you
have in mind for automakers

if they are facing reduced
incentives to buy an EV?

It’s a real risk, because the 
average EV would be 15 to 20%

more expensive to consumers in
the absence of the tax credit.

And we have already seen
a slump in demand for EVs

from consumers prior to any
cutbacks to the tax credits.

Automakers have actually reduced
their plans, to some extent,
to electrify their entire fleets.

So they again need to make the case for
the continued existence of the tax credits.

And the other strategy is a cost cutting
strategy to reduce the period until

electric vehicles become cost competitive
with internal combustion engine vehicles.

We're not far from it, we’re the
point of what we call cost parity,

so that they would no longer be
dependent on government support.

What implications would the
proposed policy shifts have

for domestic manufacturing
of EVs and their components,

especially regarding U.S. reliance on
critical materials sourced from China?

So the tax credits come with so
called local content requirements.

For an electric vehicle to be
eligible for these tax credits,

a good share of the components needs to be
sourced or produced in the United States.

And cutting back these tax credits
doesn't just impact the automakers,
it impacts entire supply chains.

So all of these efforts would kind of
suffer from a cutback of the tax credits.

In your new research you've
compared the adoption of EVs

and the development of charging
infrastructure in Germany and in California.
Why did you explore this topic?

And then we'd love to hear
some of your key takeaways.

So electrification of transportation is a core
decarbonization strategy for the economy.

And especially with regard to
2030 emission reduction targets,
the transport sector is front and center.

California and Germany both are
self declared climate leaders;

they have relatively
ambitious emission targets.
But on electrifying transportation,

California is way ahead of
Germany on a number of metrics,

including the rollout of
public charging infrastructure.

So we were trying to
understand why is that.

Please tell us a few of your key findings
and which surprised you the most.

When we think about making progress
towards a clean energy economy,

we often think about the
cost of clean technologies.

It's higher than the
technologies we have right now.

And cost is a big problem,
but it's not the only one.

As you deploy more and
more clean technologies,

you start changing the
entire technological system,

and you need to coordinate different parts,
especially technology and infrastructure.

So it's not that a single
player can change the system.

Multiple companies
need to move in sync.

So they need to resolve
the coordination problem.

And here we have a
coordination problem between

automakers selling EVs
and electric utilities,

and other new startups selling
charging infrastructure,
providing charging infrastructure.

What we found is that
this coordination problem

was resolved much better in
California than in Germany.

There was more alignment.
There were incentives for utilities

in California to invest in
charging infrastructure,

and that has a lot to do with the
regulated nature of the electricity market

where utilities are rewarded
for capital investments

into things like power plants,
but also charging infrastructure.

And in Germany,
in a liberalized electricity market,

utilities were not really
having a viable business model

for charging
infrastructure immediately.

So they weren't really
coming on board,

and this chicken and egg
problem between supplying EVs

and the charging infrastructure
wasn't instantly resolved.

What would you say the lessons
are for the United States?

Well, I think the bigger lessons really
revolve around the issue of coordination,

which is popping up in
so many different ways.

Charging infrastructure
for EVs is just one case.

We have the same between
rolling out renewables further
and building out transmission grid,

or between expanding wind and solar
energy and bringing energy storage

into the grid to accommodate these
new intermittent energy sources.

And we need to think about which
of these coordination problems

can private sector actors
solve themselves,

and where does the
government need to come in?

And we're only beginning to understand
really what the different roles are.

There are a bunch of problems
that firms can resolve themselves.

For instance, we talk a lot
about vertical coordination
versus horizontal coordination.
What does that mean?

So vertical coordination means
coordinating along the supply chains,

bringing suppliers and
buyers all in line.

And that can happen through
collaborative strategies

or through vertical integration
that one company does it all.
That was Tesla’s strategy.

They got into the EV market by
having in house battery manufacturing

and by providing their own
charging infrastructure.

So that was one way through
this vertical integration,

how they could be a leader without any
other players already providing that.

And then horizontal coordination relates
to coordinating around competitors.

That's for instance,
around technical standards,

like having the same plugin standard
that every car produced by U.S. automakers
can use the same plugs.

Firms can resolve a
lot of these problems.

But then there are some where,
especially around infrastructure,
transmission grid, or energy storage,

where government needs to either remove
barriers to building that infrastructure,
or also incentives

to make the infrastructure
build out economically viable.

So Jonas, you recently did some
work involving central banks.

Tell us about it.
And what sparked your interest?

The energy transition and climate
change entail a lot of risks
for the global economy.

And those risks are the physical
risks of climate change itself,

the droughts, the fires, 
water shortages,

extreme weather events that
threaten economic assets.

But then there are also the
risks of the energy transition,
like stranded asset risks,

so the loss of profit from
retiring fossil fuel assets early,

but also the risks that are related
to nuclear energy investments
in less mature technologies.

And in recent years, over the last
decade, central banks have begun to

manage these risks out of a
concern that they may impact

financial stability or
macroeconomic stability.

So central banks really have taken
actions along two dimensions.

One set of action is about
what we call rerisking;

embedding these physical climate
risks and the stranded asset risks

back into financial
management practices.

So that's essentially the
prudential risk management role
that central banks have always played.

A second set of actions that they're taking
is what we call the derisking action.

That's actually lowering the risk
of going to a clean energy economy,

lowering the risk of
clean energy investments.

That's less a prudential
risk management role,
much more of a promotional role,

shifting the economy towards
a clean energy economy.

We see a lot of activity on both,
but central banks vary how much they are

on the rerisking side,
the derisking side, or do both a lot.

There are few kind of leaders
that do a lot of both –

the European Central Bank, 
the Bank of England,
but also the Central Bank of China.

And why does the central bank do it,
versus why does another bank not do it?

From a kind of technocratic
mindset, we would assume that

where the risks are larger,
central banks will manage most.

But what we actually find is that
that's not necessarily the case.

What we find is that it's more
where there's already a lot of

political and policy action
around climate change.

In those countries,
central banks are also taking action.

So there are essentially
complementing strong climate policies,

as opposed to substituting for the lack
of climate and clean energy policies.

You just mentioned that China's central
bank is very active on this front.

Does that put United States
businesses at a disadvantage?

I mean, this is an early stage
where a lot of these activities

are information gathering,
understanding the magnitude of these risks.

These measures that actually provide
easier access to finance to firms,
are still not too large in magnitude.

I think the U.S. is interesting,
because the central bank hasn't taken,

the Fed hasn't taken much action
in rerisking or just derisking.

It's really in our scores
at the very low end on both.

But central banks are not the
only actors trying to manage
these new climate transition risks.

Financial supervisors are
also exploring this space.

And last year,
the Securities and Exchange Commission

developed a climate
risk disclosure rule,

which is one of these measures that in
other places central banks are pursuing.

I mean, right now it's
facing legal challenges,

but that's where another actor
than the central bank took action.

What will you be watching in
the weeks and months to come?

Well, I think over the longer term, I'm
really curious how this broader ecosystem

of managing climate and
transition risk is evolving.
But I mentioned there are others.

Financial supervisors is one group,
and yet another one is private actors.
Like credit rating agencies,

that built climate risk and
transition risk assessments

into ratings for companies,
but also for countries.

I'll be watching that space
in particular to understand

what the broader risk
management landscape looks like.

You recently did some
research into how countries
have been managing energy transitions.

Tell us about that research and
what some of your top findings are.

So the clean energy transition
is a global trend, a macro force.

But countries move along at very
different paces, some lead, some lag.

And in this project, we really
wanted to understand why is that?

And we went back into history to
understand how countries responded

to the oil shock of the early 70s, with
 transitioning away from imported oil.

And what we found is that
there are really two pathways

through which countries tackle the
main problem in energy transitions.

And what I see to be
the main problem is

political resistance
towards that transition.

Investing in new energy
technologies is costly.

And if government tries to force
companies and households to do that,

there might be a lot of
political resistance.

So the question is,
how can governments adopt policies

that promote this transition against
a lot of political opposition?

And one of these two pathways
is what we call insulation.

If the government is
insulated from voter backlash

or from business backlash politically,
then they can adopt these policies.

And that happens often when they
have a strong autonomous bureaucracy,

where career bureaucrats make essentially
in a very technocratic fashion,

rules that shift the energy
economy to a new technology future.

And historically,
we've seen this in the case of France,

where a strong ministry forced
the state-owned electricity sector

to scale nuclear at
rapid pace in the 70s.

Électricité de France,
the state-owned electricity monopolist,

then became the champion
of nuclear globally.

Today, surprisingly,
California is pursuing this model.

In California,
it's the California Resources Board,

an agency, an environment agency that
grew out of managing air pollution,

and that's taken on a very strong role in
climate, and is adopting rule after rule

and pushing ahead the California
clean energy transition.

So that's this kind of
bureaucratic insulation path.
A different path is compensation.

When a country doesn't really
have these types of agencies,

it needs to strike a deal with those
suffering from or having to absorb

the adjustment costs towards a clean
energy future; companies and households.

And we've seen this in the past, 
and today in Germany.

In the 70s, Germany wanted to also reduce
oil imports as all western economies,

and it imposed a gas tax,
a higher gas tax on its domestic economy.

It imposed a coal penny on
electricity users to then subsidize,

compensate electric utilities for
expanding coal and nuclear generation.
So that was the steel.

Costs on one side, or sticks on one hand,
and then carrots, subsidies on the other.

They repeated that in the
contemporary clean energy transition
with the coal phase out.

So Germany has a lot of
domestic lignite coal,

but that needs to be phased
out to reach emission targets.

And policymakers negotiated a deal with
electric utilities and mining regions

worth 40 billion to phase out,
but that money then helped diversify,

like helped those regions
to diversify economically.

And what made this
really a stable bargain

was that there were
pre-existing negotiating tables,

long standing relationships
between business and government,

so that business could
actually rely on this deal,

sticking around when the next
administration comes into power

and adjusting their
investment accordingly.
So these are two very distinct paths.

Now the United States, it doesn't 
have really the institutions

that enable either
insulation or compensation.

And from early efforts in the
1990s to establish an energy tax,
to the failure of cap and trade bill,

they tried to do that,
 impose policies,

but because they couldn't really
effectively insulate from voter backlash

or compensate voters and
businesses, it never happened.

So the U.S. has adopted
its very own style,

not pursue any kind of policies that
impose costs on consumers and businesses,
but just bankroll the transition.

That's the IRA.
It's a massive carrots-only approach

to dealing with the political
opposition to a clean energy transition.

Are there any lessons for the United
States? I'm sure there are many.

Well, I think if you cannot
impose these policies

that have visible costs for consumers,
then it's about dispersed costs.

And that's the case of the IRA, really
it's the budget that absorbs these costs.

And so every single taxpayer
is not really that impacted.

The costs are spread a lot across
many, as opposed to more few,
and the costs are much less visible

than if the government were to raise
the gas tax or to use a carbon tax.

Could you name like three
leaders and three laggards?

A lot of countries in continental
Europe have these institutions.

Some are heavier on the installation
piece, a lot use the compensation piece,
and they have made relative progress.

China, of course,
they have an authoritarian system
which affords a lot of insulation.
Not absolute insulation,

but that's one part of the Chinese
story of the clean energy transition,

that the government has the political
means to overcome any potential opposition.

Please tell us about the paper
that you just published in Nature.

So this paper makes the statement that
we're in a new era of climate action.

The first 30 years of climate
action were about global cooperation

on divvying up the costs of
mitigation of decarbonization.

Countries gathered
in the United Nations

and engaged in what they
called burden sharing,

how much should each
country reduce emissions?

And it was all about absorbing costs,
because clean technologies were costly.

But in the last few years,
we have entered to some extent a new era,
where it's not about corporation costs,

but competition for the
benefits of decarbonization.

And that is because clean energy
technologies have become cost competitive,
or are very close to it.

So now economies are vying for
stakes in green industries,

because they see these as strategic
sectors that can fuel future growth.
That's a very different dynamic.

So now countries are adopting
their own industrial policies

to support the domestic
green industries,

and often do so in response
to other countries.

China was first, and then Europe
and the U.S. responded to that,

and other countries, South Korea, have all
come in, Japan, and we see this green race.
And that's a very, very different dynamic.

It raises big questions, how countries 
should design these policies

to really effectively turn
taxpayer money into viable,
economically competitive industries,

but also how to make
sure that globally

this doesn't just lead
to a lose/lose or a battle

for shares in industries,
but that there is cooperation on

scaling these industries and collectively
achieving global decarbonization.

So is this good news for
climate tech entrepreneurs?

It's certainly good news
that a range of technologies

are reaching maturity and cost
competitiveness in markets.

It's only, I would say,
a good third of the climate problem,

because that's what's happening
in the electricity sector

and in the transportation sector,
with renewables and with electric vehicles.

But two thirds of the rest of
the emissions are sectors where

we have still technologies that
are much more nascent, early stage,

where we need to either have
breakthroughs in the lab

that brings us new technologies
that are much cheaper,

or drive existing technologies down the
cost curve to make them competitive.

Does your research then suggest
that CEOs of big companies

now realize that climate
technology and climate solutions

is essential for them to
survive in the long run?

I think that's certainly
a wake up moment.

I mean, the Climate Solution
State of HBS has shown this,

that more and more public
companies in the U.S.

are bringing climate
solutions to market.

And over the last five plus years,
I think climate has gone mainstream.

And it's a realization across industries
that decarbonization is a macro trend.
It's not just an energy sector story.

It affects energy intensive manufacturing,
it affects financial services.

It's really a broad technological
transformation we're witnessing.
